author: sky.cactus
content: One could call the beacon deposit contract a system contract.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is just a regular contract, but some parts of the internal system have its address hard coded.

author: ralexstokes
content: do they? i would think only as an optimization

author: ralexstokes
content: i'd say the deposit contract is an example of doing the task in user space

author: ralexstokes
content: there have been designs for "contracts" that live under an address inside the EVM/state but have special semantics

author: sky.cactus
content: Beacon chain references it directly I believe.

author: ralexstokes
content: only in as much as an eth2 client needs to know where to look for deposit logs

author: ralexstokes
content: i could boot w/ the wrong deposit contract address and i would just see inconsistent state

author: sky.cactus
content: > It is just a regular contract, but some parts of the internal system have its address hard coded.

author: __lithp__
content: If anyone here runs an archive node I would greatly appreciate an opcode trace for transaction 0xffceaac218b0414ee3d46902b1674d6036c6625002a4ecfb9939e32ef8539283

author: __lithp__
content: I'm trying to debug what I think might be a problem with Turbogeth, which seems to get the wrong answer for this transaction

author: lightclient
content: you try to get access to one of these? https://archivenode.io/

author: __lithp__
content: Didn't know this existed! Just requested access, but hoping there's a way to get a trace for this txn which doesn't require waiting 72 hours ðŸ™‚

author: __lithp__
content: Thanks for the link

author: sky.cactus
content: I think QuikNode.io has a free tier that gives a very limited number of archival node calls per month.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you only need 1, this is probably a good solution.

author: __lithp__
content: Beautiful, thank you! trying that now
